intro: Atriplex crispa, commonly known as the sandmat, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of the Americas. It is a member of the Amaranthaceae family and is characterized by its succulent, crinkled leaves that help reduce water loss in dry environments. The plant produces small, greenish flowers arranged in clusters, which are typically wind-pollinated. Atriplex crispa is often found growing in sandy soils and is adapted to withstand high temperatures and low moisture. Its ability to thrive in harsh conditions makes it an important species in ecological restoration projects.
